mainEntity.name: What is the R-value of spray foam per inch?

acceptedAnswer.text: Closed-cell spray foam provides R-6.0 to R-7.0 per inch (aged R-value), while open-cell spray foam provides R-3.5 to R-3.9 per inch. These values come from Building Science Corporation's residential spray foam guide.

mainEntity.name: Which has higher R-value: open-cell or closed-cell?

acceptedAnswer.text: Closed-cell spray foam has nearly double the R-value per inch (R-6 to R-7) compared to open-cell (R-3.5 to R-3.9). However, both provide effective air sealing, so the real-world performance difference is often smaller than the numbers suggest.

mainEntity.name: How thick should spray foam be in an attic?

acceptedAnswer.text: Attic thickness depends on your climate zone. To meet 2021 IECC requirements of R-49 to R-60: Closed-cell needs 7.5 to 10 inches, Open-cell needs 13 to 17 inches, or a Flash-and-batt hybrid with 2 inches closed-cell plus R-36-47 fiberglass.

mainEntity.name: Does spray foam lose R-value over time?

acceptedAnswer.text: Minimal loss occurs — a fraction of a percent over the life of the insulation. The R-values advertised by manufacturers are 'aged' values that already account for initial thermal drift. Spray foam maintains its performance for 50-80 years.

mainEntity.name: What R-value do I need for my climate zone?

acceptedAnswer.text: Requirements range from R-30 (warm climates, Zone 1) to R-60+ (cold climates, Zones 4-8) for attic insulation, and R-13 to R-20+ for walls. Check the 2021 IECC requirements for your specific climate zone and application.

mainEntity.name: How does spray foam R-value compare to fiberglass?

acceptedAnswer.text: Spray foam provides R-3.5 to R-7.0 per inch versus fiberglass at R-3.2 to R-3.8 per inch. More importantly, spray foam also provides complete air sealing, which fiberglass cannot. This air sealing often matters more than the R-value difference.

mainEntity.name: Is spray foam worth the higher cost?

acceptedAnswer.text: For most applications, yes. Energy savings of 30-50% (compared to 20-30% for fiberglass) typically provide a 3-7 year payback. Spray foam also lasts 50-80 years compared to 10-25 years for fiberglass, provides structural benefits, and requires no replacement.

mainEntity.name: What is the minimum thickness for effective air sealing?

acceptedAnswer.text: Closed-cell spray foam requires a minimum of 2 inches to create an effective air barrier. Open-cell spray foam requires 3 inches minimum. Below these thicknesses, air can still pass through the foam.

mainEntity.name: Can I achieve R-49 with spray foam alone?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. R-49 requires approximately 7.5 inches of closed-cell or 13 inches of open-cell spray foam. Flash-and-batt hybrid systems (2 inches closed-cell plus fiberglass batts) offer a cost-effective alternative while maintaining air-sealing benefits.

@graph.name: How to Calculate Required Spray Foam Thickness
@graph.description: Simple formula to calculate the spray foam thickness needed to achieve your target R-value

step.name: Determine Required R-Value
step.text: Check your climate zone requirements. Attics typically need R-49 to R-60, walls need R-13 to R-20+.

step.name: Identify Foam Type R-Value
step.text: Closed-cell provides R-6.5 per inch. Open-cell provides R-3.7 per inch.

step.name: Apply the Formula
step.text: Required Thickness = Target R-Value ÷ R-Value Per Inch. For example, R-30 ÷ 6.5 = 4.6 inches of closed-cell.

step.name: Consider Hybrid Options
step.text: For cost savings, use 2 inches closed-cell (R-13) plus fiberglass batts to reach higher R-values like R-49.
